utterances: When we came out here several months ago, you didn't hear a peep, not a bird, not an insect, nothing.
So that is actually a great sign.
I mean, that's life.
That's something out here that's able to survive.
They can fly in and out, pick up some food, maybe nest on top of a debris field.
I mean, they're doing fine.
The storms were particularly hard on alligators.
Locals say they seldom see the familiar snout and eyes poking out of the murky waters these days.
There is one place though where there are still numerous.
My name is Kevin Sagrera.
I live in Abbeville, Louisiana; part owner of Vermillion Gator Farms.
Rita inundated vermillion Gator Farms, washing away 3,000 squirming baby reptiles.
Though the Sagrera family raises its own gators, the farm nevertheless, depends on natural habitat.
They collect eggs from the wild, and in return release 14 percent of hatchlings back into the marsh.
(Singing) Just in case you ever change your mind.
If you suddenly decide to give me one more try.
I'll be waning in the wanes just looking for a sign just in case you change your mind.
They wanted to make sure none of those would take a hit if Dont Ask, Dont Tell is repealed.
It's obviously a sensitive time - drawing down forces in Iraq, and ramping up combat forces in Afghanistan.
So the Pentagon wanted to make sure none of these would be damaged.
And the big finding here: Most service members say they're fine with the idea of repealing Don't Ask, Don't Tell.
Indeed.
It's important to walk through some of the most important numbers.
The Pentagon sent out 400,000 surveys, Robert, to people in uniform; 145,000 of them responded.
And out of that number, 70 percent said that allowing gays to serve openly would have a positive, mixed or no effect at all.
Sixty-nine percent said they have served with a co-worker that they believed to be gay.
But there is what the Pentagon calls a significant minority of people who oppose the idea of gays serving openly.
That's - 30 percent of respondents felt that way.
And the number is higher among combat branches.
Those are the folks in the trenches, fighting wars.
That number is 48 percent in the Army, 58 percent in the Marines.
And does this - does the study say what those people - the ones who have concerns - what their concerns are with repealing Don't Ask, Don't Tell?

Well, the task force evaluating this said they repeatedly heard views that allowing openly gay service members would lead to overt effeminacy among men and homosexual promiscuity, even harassment and fears of sexual or romantic advances.
And people were also concerned about an overall erosion of standards or conduct.
Again, this is coming primarily from combat troops, most of whom have never served with someone who is gay.
But when those troops were asked if they have served with someone they believed to be gay, the level of comfort moving forward with repeal was around 90 percent.
Secretary of Defense Robert Gates told reporters he respects all of those concerns that some troops might have, but he believes the report proves repeal can move forward.
Let's take a listen.
This can be done, and should be done, without posing a serious risk to military readiness.

However, these findings do lead me to conclude that an abundance of care and preparation is required if we are to avoid a disruptive and potentially dangerous impact on the performance of those serving at the tip of the spear in America's wars.
Robert, the takeaway today being, the secretary of Defense says repeal can happen, but there needs to be significant time to train and prepare forces for that change.
And what's the next step in this process?
Well, the next step - Secretary Gates is now urging Congress to repeal.
But again, that'll be up to Congress to see if they can push that through.
OK, thank you, Rachel.
NPR's Rachel Martin at the Pentagon.
NPR's business news starts with China banking on the United States.
All that money we've been sending to China to buy stuff, they're happy to lend it back to us.
The Federal Reserve said it's allowing China's biggest lender to open up shop in the United States.
The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China - or ICBC - will open its first branch in New York.
The Chinese government owns 75 percent of that bank.
Goldman Sachs owns a small stake.
The move is a switch from past years, when U.S.
negotiators used to push China to open up its market to U.S.
banks.
That was back in the old days, when American banks had money.
Now Chinese officials are urging the U.S.
to speed up applications by Chinese banks to establish branches here.
ICBC is actually the second bank in the last two months to be allowed to offer banking services in the U.S.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
Health care remains the big issue in Washington.
The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Max Baucus of Montana, unveiled his bill yesterday.
Last week, President Obama addressed a joint session of Congress and gave us a clearer idea of his plans for health care.
With so much unanswered in the health care debate, we asked listeners to send us their questions about it and many did.
Now, we're going to try to answer a few of those questions with the help of our resident expert, NPR health policy correspondent, Julie Rovner.
Good to see you again, Julie.
Nice to be here.
We're going to begin with listener Carol Urbanick(ph) of Columbus, Ohio, who wants to know about mandates.
Specifically, how will mandated insurance coverage be enforced?
Well, there is a long answer and a short answer.
I will not go through the entire long answer because it differs with the different bills.
The short answer is there will be exemptions for people who truly don't have enough money to afford coverage.
People who are poor, people who have legitimate religious reasons not to have traditional health coverage.
Meaning, you can't just establish the church of my Toyota doesn't run this week.
Everyone else who doesn't have coverage will be assessed a penalty through the tax system.
In other words, if you can't demonstrate you have coverage, you will be charged some kind of an extra tax penalty at the end of the year.
But when would somebody know whether I have insurance or not, on my tax returns or...
Yes, that's in all likelihood.
That's how it's done in Massachusetts, where they have this.
I assume that's how it will be done here.
Okay.
Next, to Austin, Texas, and listener Joel Keys(ph) who writes this: Assuming there are 45 million uninsured people in the U.S.

and that most, say, 90 percent typically don't go to a health care provider, as a result of not having insurance, can the health care system - doctors, nurses, hospitals, clinics - handle the 40 million new patients if they all got health insurance tomorrow?
Well, they're obviously not all getting health insurance tomorrow.
Even if this bill was to pass tomorrow, they wouldn't get coverage the next day.
The good or bad of these bills is that they mostly don't take effect until the year 2013, four years from now.
That's largely because that's how long it takes to get this new marketplace and the new insurance programs up and running.
Is DeLay's resignation good news for Republicans running for reelection in November?
Is there enough time now for them to distance themselves from the lobbying scandal?
Good morning.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
If you want to be governor of Kansas, there turn out to be standards after all.
Terran Woolley proved it.
He read stories that six teenagers filed to run for governor because the state has no age limit or other qualifications.
So Mr. Woolley decided to file paperwork to run his 3-year-old dog, Angus.
But the state disqualified Angus, saying he's not capable of fulfilling the responsibilities.
Oh, come on, he's loyal and doesn't lie.
It's MORNING EDITION.
Bobby Osborne has a lot to celebrate.
The bluegrass musician turns 86 years old today.
He recently released a new album.

And later this month, he will mark the 50th anniversary of the song that became the Osborne Brothers' signature, ""Rocky Top."" Jewly Hight of our member station WPLN took a drive with Osborne down memory lane.
If I get on the street, I'll know the house and everything.
Bobby Osborne is trying to find his way back to the lakeside home where he first heard ""Rocky Top.
I think this was a big field when I moved here.
This Nashville suburb's been transformed by half a century's worth of development.
And Johnny Cash lived here.
And he lived at a way (unintelligible), but he was right on the lake.
GPS guides us off a busy road and into a serene neighborhood.
This is the street, I guess.
But it - they lived at a dead end.
It's probably not there no more.
The house once belonged to the legendary songwriting couple Felice and Boudleaux Bryant.
It's still there, but the dead end has become a cul-de-sac.
Yeah.
Osborne stares out the car window, reminiscing about the afternoon that Boudleaux sat in an easy chair and strummed through an unfinished song he thought the brothers might like.
Boudleaux had a kind of a low voice.
And he would sing it like this, (singing) wish that I was on old rocky top, down into (unintelligible) hills.
He sang the words to it slow and played it...
Slower and lower.
Yeah.
Oh, yeah.
The Osborne Brothers came up with a different way of doing it.
